p: Although vector abundance data directly from the two regions of the outbreak were not available, we tested the applicability of the albopictus model over a preliminary surveillance dataset comprising ovitrap samplings in four towns, Ravenna, Forli, Cesena, and Rimini, during the period of the chikungunya outbreak in Italy [ 79]. We employed the same posterior parameter set Î˜4 (see Vector dynamics model) calibrated on the Emilia-Romagna region. In Fig 5(a), we plot model prediction against the average number of eggs collected per ovitrap for each town. The prediction is in agreement with the data with a certain proportionality constant (0.75). Scaling with a proportionality constant was necessary due to the model output being normalised with respect to the number of ovitraps as placed in the Carrieri et al. 2011 surveillance study [ 50].
